title: 104_hr4016
content: The "Drug-Free Schools Reform Act of 1996" is cited as the short title. It amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to include State Grants for Drug and Violence Prevention Programs. The "Drug-Free Schools Reform Act of 1996" reserves funds for grants to Guam, American Samoa, the Virgin Islands, and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, as well as for programs for Indian youth. The "Drug-Free Schools Reform Act of 1996" reserves funds for programs for Indian youth, with specific allocations for national impact evaluation and programs for Native Hawaiians. State allotments are determined based on the school-aged population of each State. The "Drug-Free Schools Reform Act of 1996" reserves funds for programs for Indian youth and Native Hawaiians based on state allotments determined by the school-aged population. States receive allotments based on a formula considering the previous year's funding and a minimum allocation requirement. The Secretary can reallot funds if necessary. The Secretary can reallot funds to States if unable to use within two years. Definitions include 'State' as 50 States, DC, Puerto Rico, and 'local educational agency' as educational service agencies and consortia. SEC. 4112. State applications. To receive funding under section 4111, the State's chief executive officer must submit an application to the Secretary. The application must describe how funds will be coordinated with other programs, including those under the Goals 2000: Educate America Act. Additionally, it should include the State's needs assessment for drug and violence prevention programs based on ongoing evaluation activities. The State's application for funding under section 4111 must include data on drug use and violence among youth, cooperation with national impact evaluations, and any other required information. The Secretary will use a peer review process to review State applications. The State's application for funding under section 4111 must include data on drug use and violence among youth, cooperation with national impact evaluations, and any other required information. The Secretary will use a peer review process to review State applications. SEC. 4113. STATE PROGRAMS. The chief executive officer of a State must use allocated funds for drug and violence prevention programs. Administrative costs are limited to 5% of the total amount received. Grants and contracts are exclusively for financing authorized programs. The funds allocated for prevention programs must be used exclusively for teaching the dangers of drug use and underage drinking. Any expenditure on non-anti-drug programs will be considered a violation. Expenditures on non-anti-drug programs will be considered a violation, with penalties including forfeiture and reimbursement. Grants or contracts awarded must undergo peer review. State chief executive officers can directly carry out activities or use grants/contracts. Law enforcement education partnerships can receive grants from funds allocated for prevention programs. The officer will use funds to award grants to law enforcement agencies for drug abuse and violence prevention activities, including programs like Drug Abuse Resistance Education and Project Legal Lives. Programs like Project Legal Lives involve district attorneys providing classroom instruction on the law and legal system through interactive learning techniques, such as mock trial competitions. Other initiatives include partnerships between law enforcement and child guidance professionals, as well as before- and after-school activities. "SEC. 4114. EVALUATION AND REPORTING." The Secretary will conduct a biennial evaluation of national impact on programs combating violence in schools and submit findings to the President and Congress. Data collection will be done by the National Center for Education Statistics. Education Statistics will collect data on violence in elementary and secondary schools, using information provided by the States. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress by January 1, 2000, with recommendations and estimated costs for implementing them. States must submit a report by October 1, 1999, and every third year thereafter. The chief executive officer of the State must submit a report to the Secretary every third year by October 1, starting in 1999, detailing the implementation and outcomes of State programs under section 4113, along with an assessment of their effectiveness. The report should be in a specified form, based on ongoing evaluation activities, and include data on drug use and violence by youth in schools and communities. The State must submit a report every third year detailing the implementation and outcomes of State programs under section 4113, including data on drug use and violence by youth in schools and communities, which should be made readily available to the public. "Programs for Native Hawaiians are outlined in SEC. 4114." The Secretary will provide grants or agreements to organizations serving Native Hawaiians recognized by the Governor of Hawaii to implement programs for their benefit. Native Hawaiian is defined as individuals with ancestors native to the area before 1778. Ancest Native Hawaiians are individuals with ancestors native to the area before 1778.
